data.title: The 50 best fantasy movies of all time
data.meta_description: From classic like 'King Kong' to groundbreaking masterpieces such as â€˜Lord of the Ringsâ€™, we count down the 50 best fantasy movies ever made
data.text:
Once thought of as the exclusive province of nerds playing Dungeons & Dragons in their parentsâ€™ basements, fantasy movies are now huge business. Peter Jacksonâ€™s Lord of the Rings trilogy changed the game, while Game of Thrones, Stranger Things and the Marvel Cinematic Universe made it clear that the geeks have inherited the earth.

And thank goodness, really. No genre can transport you to a different place better than fantasy, and in this day and age we need all the escapist entertainment we can get. But for the purposes of this list, weâ€™re not limiting the definition of â€˜fantasyâ€™ to swords-and-dwarves epics and superhero flicks. Youâ€™ll find plenty of those, sure. But youâ€™ll also find movies of a more surreal bent, and some that reimagine our own planet as a place where magic, mystery and adventure is easy to find, if you know where to look.

The Marvel Cinematic Universe boldly straddles sci-fi, comic-book action and fantasy â€“ never more so than in the â€˜Thorâ€™ movies, with their Tolkein-influenced take on Norse mythology and outrageous â€˜Flash Gordonâ€™-style fetish costumes. â€˜Thorâ€™ is essentially a reboot of â€˜Masters of the Universeâ€™ â€“ bulging hero heads to Earth to battle skeletal psychopath â€“ but with better special effects and more nod-wink humour.

Magic moment: The glistening CG cityscape of Asgard couldâ€™ve come straight from a mid-70s Rick Wakeman LP cover.

Tom Huddleston

Terry Gilliam gave his imagination full reign in this wild, woolly and weird time-hopping comedy for smarter kids. Packed with historical heroes, diminutive hustlers, post-Python humour, loopy cameos and bizarre fantastical asides â€“ not to mention the bleakest, strangest ending imaginable â€“ the film was an unlikely transatlantic smash hit.

Magic moment: David Warnerâ€™s petrifying Evil transforms into the universeâ€™s creepiest fairground ride.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

Shangri-La is the ultimate earthbound fantasy â€“ an ancient magical kingdom buried deep in the Himalayas, ruled by peaceful Tibetan philosophers who have discovered the secret of eternal youth. Frank Capraâ€™s adaptation of James Hiltonâ€™s hugely successful, Hitler-inspiring novel is a glorious, naÃ¯ve fantasy adventure, the most expensive movie ever made at the time.

Magic moment: Ronald Colmanâ€™s climactic realisation that it was all real â€“ and he has to get back there! â€“ is pure, giddy wish-fulfilment.

Tom Huddleston

A pair of grieving elf brothers turn to magic to reanimate, for 24 emotional hours, the dad they never really knew. But the spell is broken halfway through, leaving them with, well, half a dad. With only the legs operational and the missing top half flopping around under layers of clothes, the three bluff their way through a quest to find a magical gem and finish the job. Set in a fantastical land populated by evolved cyclops, fauns, mages and all manner of mythical fauna who have switched from magic to mod cons, â€˜Onwardâ€™ is a cometh-of-age tale that makes playful capital from our habit of turning the past into touristy kitsch.

Magic moment: When Ian listens to a tape of the dad he never knew and you wish you'd remember to bulk-buy tissues.

Advertising

Begun in Britain but completed in California following the outbreak of war, this spectacular adventure based on tales from â€˜1001 Nightsâ€™ may have had a piecemeal production â€“ and no less than six directors, including the mighty Michael Powell â€“ but you wouldnâ€™t guess it from the result. Crammed with magical horses, terrifying transformations and gigantic genies, â€˜The Thief of Baghdadâ€™ made an international star of low-born Indian actor Sabu, aka the Elephant Boy.

Magic moment: We all dream of having three wishes â€“ but how many of us would ask for sausages?

Tom Huddleston

Now one of the highest-grossing films of all time, â€˜Black Pantherâ€™ is not just an important movie, itâ€™s also a great movie. With an almost entirely black cast, a black director and black writers, the film is a thrilling exploration of afro-futurism, cultural oppression and revolution. Its story is magnificent, too, proving it to be one of the Marvel Cinematic Universeâ€™s best standalone outing, and the acting feels electric, with the performances by Boseman, Jordan and Wright really standing out. Itâ€™s that rare breed of superhero movie thatâ€™s worthy of repeated viewings.

Magic Moment: Without a doubt, our first glimpse of Wakanda.

Alim Kheraj

Advertising

When Mikeyâ€™s family home faces foreclosure, he and his misfit friends know itâ€™s up to them to save it â€“ thatâ€™s when they discover a treasure map and set off into an underground cave system to find the loot, putting them at odds with a fearsome criminal family. Itâ€™s really no wonder why this Steven Spielberg-produced, Chris Columbus-penned, Richard Donner-directed adventure has endured for generations: itâ€™s made up of all the stuff kids dream about. Hidden pirate gold? Mean but bumbling bad guys? A hideously deformed monster who turns out to have a heart of gold (and a taste for Baby Ruths)? More than anything, The Goonies taps into the irresistible idea that even the sleepiest of towns hold big secrets â€“ you just need the right buddies to help you undercover them.

Magic moment: the reveal of One-Eyed Willieâ€™s treasure-filled galleon is eye-popping and heart-swelling.

Matthew Singer

Writer-director Guillermo del Toro is the most original and uncompromising cinema fantasist of the modern era, and â€˜Panâ€™s Labyrinthâ€™ is his most striking statement. This gruesome, disquieting coming-of-age story draws on ancient influences â€“ the central thread of a young woman drawn into terrible, otherworldly danger goes right back to â€˜Little Red Riding Hoodâ€™ and beyond â€“ and adds an unflinching depiction of the brutality of war.

Magic moment: Does any single image better encapsulate the darker side of fantasy than the hideous Pale Man, with eyes in the palms of his hands?

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

Not the first name you associate with fantasy, but Woody Allen pulled off one of his more out-there conceits with this tribute to the transportive power of the movies. It tells of a housewife (Mia Farrow) who, during the Depression, is swept off her feet by her favourite movie character (Jeff Daniels), who steps down from the screen and sweeps her into a heady romance. It gives a whole new meaning to the idea of the fantasy movie.

Magic moment: The â€˜left behindâ€™ characters in the movie, who sit bickering after their hero has departed for the â€˜real worldâ€™.

Dave Calhoun

All of Wes Andersonâ€™s ornate, painstakingly precious films take place in a world just removed from our own, where anything seems possible. But he pushed that fantasy element to its extreme in â€˜The Life Aquaticâ€™, in which Bill Murray plays a globetrotting marine biologist exploring a bizarre, dayglo undersea world.

Magic moment: Whenever Seu Jorgeâ€™s plaintive, Bowie-obsessed shipâ€™s minstrel strikes up, the film enters a whole new mystical realm.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

Featuring a career-defining performance from Tilda Swinton, this Virginia Woolf adaptation from Sally Potter is a magical affair. Swinton plays Orlando, in turns a man and a woman, as s/he travels in half-century leaps from the Elizabethan court to the twentieth century, via the Civil War, early colonialism and more. Itâ€™s a sly, wise comment on things such as English history, sexuality and class, all of it wrapped in a beautiful, transporting fantasy.

Magic moment: When Orlando transforms again... and again... and again.

Dave Calhoun

Despite being famously sued by Lionel Hutz for false advertising, Wolfgang Petersenâ€™s dreamy fable endures as a childrenâ€™s classic. After ditching school to hole up in a bookstore, troubled young Bastian begins reading the tale of Atreju, a child warrior tasked with saving his homeland of Fantasia from an malignant force known as the Nothing â€“ and eventually, he becomes so consumed with the story it literally pulls him in. Mashing up various bits of traditional folklore with a Spielbergian sense of imagination â€“ and Jim Henson-esque puppetry â€“ the movie has aged incredibly well. Younger viewers will recognise the kickass theme song from Stranger Things, too.

Magic moment: Fly, Falkor, fly!

Matthew Singer

Advertising

It almost seems quaint now, what with the concept of the â€˜multiverseâ€™ having become part of the common cultural lexicon, but in 2012 seeing Iron Man, Captain America, the Incredible Hulk etc all sharing the same screen was a big freakinâ€™ deal. Cult Buffy the Vampire Slayer creator Joss Whedon was tasked with meeting the grand expectations of the Marvel faithful, and he more than delivers, somehow crafting a massive spectacle involving an all-star cast of characters where no one gets lost in the sturm und drang of it all. Endgame may have cranked everything to 11, including box-office receipts, but itâ€™s bogged down by lore and bad vibes. The original is simply exhilarating: big and loud, funny and fun, frivolous but not at all dumb. Itâ€™s truly glorious entertainment.

Magic moment: The Michael Bay-style wraparound shot showing the Avengers assembled together for the first time.

Matthew Singer

A groundbreaker in several ways, Robert Zemeckisâ€™s truly looney half-â€™toon, half-live action comedy sendup presents an alternate-dimension vision of Golden Age Hollywood, one where 2D stars like Bugs Bunny walk off the screen and commingle with their flesh-and-blood peers. Of its many innovations, the most impressive might be its deployment of a primordial multiverse concept, with characters from the Disney universe sharing space with those from Warner Bros. and Universal. Trust us: in the days before mass corporate consolidation, the idea of seeing Mickey Mouse and Daffy Duck in the same movie was mind-blowing.

Magic moment: Private investigator Eddie Valiant (Bob Hoskins) drives into Toontown, where heâ€™s serenaded by a cheery chorus of anthropomorphic trees, animals and a goofily grinning sun.

Matthew Singer

Advertising

â€˜My Neighbor Totoroâ€™ is beloved of kids around the world, but it was â€˜Princess Mononokeâ€™ more than a decade later that truly brought the films of Hayao Miyazaki to the Western world. An environmentalist epic about giant forest gods, the blind greed of human industry and a warrior princess raised by wolves, this grand fantasy story is animation on a scale unlike anything Disney has ever tried.

Magic Moment: The title character is introduced sucking poison out of a wound, blood smeared across her mouth. This isnâ€™t your traditional princess.

David Ehrlich

William Dieterleâ€™s supernatural monochrome melodrama has enjoyed a bit of a renaissance since Martin Scorsese echoed the filmâ€™s bright green lightning bolt in â€˜The Wolf of Wall Streetâ€™. Following the not not-creepy inter-dimensional love affair between a poor painter and a girl named Jennie who seems to be from the past and aging rapidly, the film is a lot to swallow, but the squall it builds to is a perfect storm of truly impossible romance.

This Magic Moment: Scorsese got it right: that first flash of colour still sends a chill up your spine.

David Ehrlich

Advertising

CGI never created anything quite so unique as special effects master Ray Harryhausenâ€™s model figures. He considered this tale from Greek mythology to be his best film. Certainly it has some of his finest creations: towering bronze giant Talos looming out of the ocean, the winged harpies and the seven headed Hydra.

Magic moment: The still-iconic fight between muscle-men and a sword-wielding skeleton army.

Cath Clarke

Swiss-cheese plotting, dodgy accents, even dodgier kilts and Queen on the soundtrack: whatâ€™s not to love about â€˜Highlanderâ€™? Why director Russell Mulcahy cast a Frenchman (Christopher Lambert) as a Scottish clansman and a Scotsman (Sean Connery) as a Spanish noble is anyoneâ€™s guess, but when the plotâ€™s this crazed, the directionâ€™s this MTV-tight and the villains are this insanely badass, weâ€™re really not about to argue.

Magic moment: Lambert and Connery practice their swordplay on a mountain-top while Freddie Mercury bellows â€˜Who Wants to Live Foreverâ€™ â€“ pure, cheeseball glory.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

The pinnacle of Wagnerian fantasy on screen, this adaptation of Robert E Howardâ€™s crypto-fascist pulp stories is so much more than just a goofy sword â€˜nâ€™ sandal throwback. The Spanish desert backdrops are stunning, the production design is spectacular and Arnold Schwarzenegger punches a camel.

Magic moment: Cannibal cultist Thulsa Doomâ€™s transformation into a giant serpent is a classic of pre-digital effects technology.

Tom Huddleston

Blending fantasy and comedy is a tricky task â€“ just ask David Gordon Green and the guys behind 2011â€™s woeful stoner spoof â€˜Your Highnessâ€™ â€“ but director Rob Reiner and author-screenwriter William Goldman made it look effortless with this feisty, fast-paced and genuinely funny fairytale. Their genius is to treat the fantastical elements completely seriously â€“ the costumes are ornate, the special effects never look goofy and the world of the film is totally convincing, allowing the humour to shine through.

Magic moment: â€˜My name is Inigo Montoya, you killed my father, prepare to die!â€™ Enough said.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

An animated version of the book â€˜Mrs Frisby and the Rats of Nimhâ€™, this is a kidsâ€™ fantasy with a big soppy heart. It tells of Mrs Frisby, a fieldmouse, widow and mother trying to look after her young brood, one of whom is very ill, in the face of threats from humans and a race of souped-up, intelligent rats. Its sense of magic and danger is heightened by the story sitting on a base of grief. It also features the least cuddly, most terrifying wise old owl you could imagine.

Magic moment: When we learn how the skulking, super-smart rats gained their powers.

Dave Calhoun

Drawing on Sufi teachings, religious tracts and surrealist art rather than the traditional Northern European folk tales, Alejandro Jodorowskyâ€™s experimental, psychedelic fantasy stands completely alone on this list. Obscure, artful and gleefully avant-garde, the film follows an acid-fried modern Jesus as he meets an alchemist and transcends through the seven levels of enlightenment.

Magic moment: Itâ€™s hardly RSPCA-approved, but the re-enactment of the Spanish conquest of South America using frogs and toads is one of the most remarkable scenes in cinema.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

Ultrastylish commercials director Tarsem Singh spent millions of his own dollars collecting footage over several years for this entrancingly exotic fantasy, rooted in the medicated ramblings of a wounded stuntman (Lee Pace) who charms a little girl in the hospital with his outlandish tales. The dreamlike story he cooks up is tinged with traumatic catastrophe, but also one of the most glorious adventures ever captured on film.

Magic moment: A breathtaking opening credits sequence, shot in slo-mo and black and white, shows a train-track stunt gone wrong.

Joshua Rothkopf

Tobey Maguire and Reese Witherspoon were plucky up-and-comers when they played a pair of siblings who are magically transported through the TV screen and into the monochrome world of Pleasantville, a happy 1950s town where everyoneâ€™s polite, prim and happy â€“ on the surface. â€˜Hunger Gamesâ€™ director Gary Rossâ€™s pin-sharp satire brilliantly undercuts the American Dream, and the visual trick of gradually shifting the film from black and white to colour to reflect the charactersâ€™ cultural awakening is masterful.

Magic moment: Repressed suburban Mom Joan Allen tries her hand at a little sexual self-fulfilment, and a tree outside the window explodes into glorious colour.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

From its very beginning, cinema was indebted to fantasy, with Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s leading the way. The ambition of todayâ€™s multi-feature sagas can be traced back to Fritz Langâ€™s two-part 1924 silent based on the mythic German poem â€˜Nibelungenliedâ€™ and lavished with groundbreaking special effects, comely princesses and tons of swordplay.

Magic moment: The first instalment, â€˜Siegfriedâ€™, features a giant, drooling dragon â€“ a fully functioning puppet thatâ€™s the grandfather of Jabba the Hutt.

Joshua Rothkopf

Itâ€™s easy to get snarky over star David Bowieâ€™s famously bulging codpiece, but Jim Hensonâ€™s fantastical childrenâ€™s adventure is a truly fun and freaky experience to watch even as an adult. A young Jennifer Connelly must venture through a magical realm full of dwarves, horned giants and fart bogs in order to rescue her baby brother from the evil Goblin King, played by Bowie with maximum glammed-up hamminess.

Magic moment: Bowieâ€™s preening, baby-juggling rendition of â€˜Dance Magicâ€™, performed a gaggle of singing, dancing Muppet monsters.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

Move over, â€˜Mulholland Driveâ€™: Jacques Rivetteâ€™s enchanting meta-fantasy begins with a distracted young woman stumbling through a Parisian park. She loses her scarf and when a curious onlooker retrieves it, the chase is on, one that plunges into exchanged female identities, interdimensional time travel and a mysterious house where nothing is set in stone.

Magic moment: The whole movie is a spell, but how can we not single out the bizarre coda of a boating scene? Reality merges with fantasy, not unpleasantly.

Joshua Rothkopf

For the follow-up to their loopy time-travel pastiche â€˜Bill & Tedâ€™s Excellent Adventureâ€™, writers Ed Solomon and Chris Matheson turned to the maddest, baddest fantasy novel of them all: The Bible. This time around, our doofus heroes from San Dimas, California are killed, condemned to hell, escape Satan, play Twister with Death, strike a bargain with God and end up saving the world through a combination of screeching guitars and extreme party vibes. Amen.

Magic moment: Bill and Ted convince St Peter to open the pearly gates by quoting Poison lyrics at him.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

If Terry Gilliam thought heâ€™d been dragged through the ringer by the studios following his brutalist sci-fi comedy â€˜Brazilâ€™, he hadnâ€™t seen nothinâ€™ yet. â€˜Baron Munchausenâ€™ became a byword for mega-budget disasters: the budget spiraled, the special effects collapsed and audiences stayed away in droves. But the film remains a wounded wonder, crammed with wild ideas, bizarre costumes, berserk characters and a unique sense of giddy, anything-goes experimentation.

Magic moment: The Baron and his sidekick Sally travel to the moon and find a Lumiere-inspired madhouse peopled with giant schizophrenics.

Tom Huddleston

The dream sequences of master director Luis BuÃ±uel are always charged with a sociopolitical dimension, and this satire â€“ one of his finest and most concentrated efforts â€“ is no exception. A group of mildly haughty, self-entitled friends attempt to sit down to dinner together. All they want is to be served, but BuÃ±uel has other plans for them.

Magic moment: Delighting at a menu of multiple fish options and a deep wine list, the party hears weeping: behind a curtain, the restaurantâ€™s manager lies dead.

Joshua Rothkopf

Advertising

Ang Leeâ€™s high-flying melodrama, a vivid reinvention of the wu-xia genre and one of only nine foreign-language movies to ever be nominated for Best Picture, is still an unimpeachably perfect combination of physical and emotional combat. The fight choreography has yet to be topped, and every balletic moment of soaring wire-fu reveals something about the character whoâ€™s swooping through the air.

This Magic Moment: The first fight scene along the rooftops in the middle of the night, as the drums pound away on Tan Dunâ€™s score. Holy hell.

David Ehrlich

Few actors have ever personified a literary character to the degree that Gene Wilder inhabited author Roald Dahlâ€™s dandy candyman, and itâ€™s really a wonder why other people keep trying. Itâ€™s not just the performance that makes the original adaptation the definitive one: with its chocolate rivers and candy meadows, the design of Wonkaâ€™s factory truly looks good enough to eat. Sure, thereâ€™s a good message in there for kids about not being a deceitful little shit, but itâ€™s delivered in a Technicolor wrapping that, even decades later, is a literal feast for the eyes.

Magic moment: Charlie and Grandpa Joe swig forbidden fizzy lifting drink, causing them to float skyward in a moment that quickly switches from magic to panic when they realise theyâ€™re heading straight for a deadly industrial ceiling fan.

Matthew Singer

Advertising

A boatload of Oscars would arrive with the next film, â€˜The Return of the Kingâ€™, but hereâ€™s where Peter Jacksonâ€™s trilogy cohered as a triumph of cutting-edge technology and emotional impact. Andy Serkisâ€™s Gollum â€“ a fully fleshed digital creation â€“ stole the show, yet this film also digs deep to depict the rallying redemption of King ThÃ©oden, from weeping at the grave of his son to leading the armies of Rohan into battle.

Magic moment: Gollum and SmÃ©agol have a psychotic conversation and never once do you think about CGI.

Joshua Rothkopf

An astonishingly poetic movie about the reunification of Germany and what it means to be human, Wim Wendersâ€™s masterful Biblical fantasy uses the gothic landscapes of divided Berlin â€“ shot in sparkling monochrome â€“ as a backdrop for a vivid exploration of the dreamlife of angels.

Magic Moment: Nothing can top that dizzying opening sequence, as two angels eavesdrop on the scattered thoughts of Berlinâ€™s residents.

David Ehrlich

Advertising

Bewitching and mesmerising, â€˜Uncle Boonmeeâ€™ is a perfect film to lose yourself in. Directed by Thai master Apichatpong Weerasethakul (his Western friends call him Joe) it unfolds in a reverie as Uncle Boonmee, a dying farmer, is visited in his final days by friends and family â€“ his nephew and sister, but also the ghost of his dead wife and a red-eyed monkey-man who says heâ€™s Boonmeeâ€™s son. Experimental and eccentric, itâ€™s unforgettable.

Magic moment: The beautiful moment Uncle Boonmee visits a cave filled with sparkling lights, and his life slips away.

Cath Clarke

â€˜Panâ€™s Labyrinthâ€™ may have won over the highbrow critics, but â€˜Hellboy IIâ€™ is fantasy master Guillermo del Toroâ€™s masterpiece. Adapted from Mike Mignolaâ€™s comic books, this sequel to the patchily brilliant superhero adventure â€˜Hellboyâ€™ crams in all the psychotic fairies, marauding elves, fantastical landscapes and berserk action set-pieces you could possibly ask for, and adds a rich seam of hearty, self-satirising humour.

Magic moment: The hidden â€˜troll marketâ€™ beneath the Brooklyn Bridge rivals the â€˜Star Warsâ€™ cantina in the monster-riot stakes.

Tom Huddleston

Advertising

In retelling Mary Shelleyâ€™s â€˜Frankensteinâ€™ story with Johnny Depp as the unfinished creation with scissors for hands, Tim Burton created a modern day classic. It could all have turned out so differently if heâ€™d gone with the studioâ€™s choice of lead actor, Tom Cruise â€“ who wanted the story to have a â€˜happier endingâ€™. Pah.

Magic moment: From his castle hideaway, Edward creates a Christmas snowstorm.

Cath Clarke

Buy, rent or watch â€˜Edward Scissorhandsâ€™

A tornado blowing in over the Kansas plains, the tap-tap-tap of the ruby slippers, the yellow brick road in glorious Technicolor and a witch the colour of alien snot. The best moments of â€˜The Wizard of Ozâ€™ are woozily eerie, like memories of a dream. The staying power of the film might have something to do with the very real emotions underpinning the fantasy: the pull for a child between home and the terrors and thrill of the big world outside.

Magic moment: The winged monkeys take flight under orders from the Wicked Witch of the West. â€˜Fly my pretties!â€™

Cath Clarke

Advertising

Itâ€™s the wellspring of modern fantasy, but cinemaâ€™s track record when it comes to the King Arthur legend is pitiful, whether itâ€™s the dippy musical fantasia of â€˜Camelotâ€™ or the dour, would-be-realism of the Clive Owen â€˜King Arthurâ€™ (and donâ€™t even get us started on Guy Ritchieâ€™s impending reboot). The only film that truly captures the grandeur of Arthurian myth is John Boormanâ€™s intermittently ridiculous but cumulatively breathtaking â€˜Excaliburâ€™, the grittiest, mistiest, earthiest British fantasy movie of them all.

Magic moment: Nicol Williamsonâ€™s bizarre, theatrical Merlin weaves a transformation spell. Altogether now: â€˜anal nathrachâ€¦ orthâ€™ bhaisâ€™s bethadâ€¦ do cheâ€™l deâ€™nmha.â€™

Tom Huddleston

Alfonso Cuaron's take on the â€˜Harry Potterâ€™ movies was when the franchise proved it was more than just a lifeless, slavish recreation of J.K. Rowling's immeasurably popular fantasy novels. Somehow, Cuaron took what is one of the series' more muted novels and adapted it into a visually sumptuous, only-just-family-friendly and truly magical film. The meditations on aging, the literal and metaphorical passing of time and our experience with youth are deftly handled, as the fat of the novel is trimmed expertly to propel both plot and characterisation. Could it be the best kids' movie of the 21st century? Possibly.

Magic moment: The filmâ€™s quietest scene is also its most magical, as the kids hang out in the dorm room passing a bag of Bertie Bottâ€™s beans and shooting the supernatural breeze.

Alim Kheraj

Advertising

Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburgerâ€™s second film on this list isnâ€™t fantasy in the strictest sense. The story of a prima ballerina (Moira Shearer) and the power-mad Svengali (Anton Walbrook) who loves and exploits her, it takes place, for the most part, in the â€˜realâ€™ world. But when the curtains go up and the ballet begins, the film spirals off into a world of dizzying make-believe, with Powell at the peak of his powers as he combines cinema, music, performance, art, costume and animation into a breathless whirl of sound and colour.

Magic moment: The heartbreaking ending, as the performers recreate the titular ballet without their star dancer, just an empty space where she should have been.

Tom Huddleston

Not every fantasy movie involves mythological creatures and epic quests in an otherworldly realm â€“ some are simply about a cranky weatherman stuck in a time loop. Sure, Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania, is pretty far from Middle Earth, and the titular â€˜giant squirrelâ€™ doesnâ€™t even talk, but Harold Ramisâ€™s classic comedy still qualifies for the genre, insofar as it uses a fantastical situation to explore what it truly means to grow as a person. Bill Murray goes peak Murricane as Phil Connors, who wakes one day to find himself trapped in a cosmic prison, forcing him to live the same day over and over and over again until he changes every shitty thing about himself. Letâ€™s just say it takes a while.

Magic moment: Phil, having reached rock bottom, declares himself a god (â€˜not the God, I donâ€™t thinkâ€™) and proceeds to reveal his omnipotence to his love interest, Andie MacDowell.

Matthew Singer

Advertising

A smash-hit in Japan, Hayao Miyazakiâ€™s family fantasy is hands-down one of the most charming films ever made. Itâ€™s the story of two sisters who move with their dad to the sticks to be close to their sick mum, and there meet a big-bummed snuggly monster with a goofy toothpaste grin and a twelve-legged cat bus.

Magic moment: All aboard the feline express.

Cath Clarke

At first Powell & Pressburgerâ€™s towering film looks like a wartime romance, which partly it is. But once David Nivenâ€™s doomed RAF pilot crashes while talking to an American radio operator (June Carter), he finds himself at the pearly gates, so introducing the filmâ€™s dual locations, earth and heaven. In the latter, a celestial court must decide if Nivenâ€™s pilot will be spared or not, and the filmâ€™s fantastical conceit taps into a postwar spirit of inquiry into how best to run our lives.

Magic moment: When we see the shimmering stairs that rise up to the heavens.

Dave Calhoun

Advertising

Haunting and inventive, this showed us the dark side of â€˜The Muppetsâ€™ ringmaster Jim Henson, who offered up a gothic world of magic and danger partly inspired by the darkness of the Grimm fairytales. Itâ€™s a classic quest story: Jen, a Gelfling, must fulfil a prophecy and defeat the ageing, decaying race of Skeksis in favour of the gentler, wiser Mystics. The filmâ€™s character design is as remarkable as its faith in the imagination of children.

Magic moment: When the Mystics and the Skeksis merge in a cosmic, psychedelic transformational orgy.

Dave Calhoun

As great as it is, Disneyâ€™s Beauty and the Beast canâ€™t hold a candle to French imagineer Jean Cocteauâ€™s live-action interpretation â€“ literally, one of the coolest bits of set design in his version is a hallway lined with disembodied human arms acting as living sconces. Seriously, though: itâ€™s one thing to animate a fairy tale, and quite another to build it for real, and Cocteau makes the 200-year-old fable about a young girlâ€™s affair with a hideous monster come alive like a vivid hallucination.

Magic moment: When Belleâ€™s tears sparkle like diamonds.

Matthew Singer

Advertising

A high point not only of the consistently excellent output of Japanâ€™s Studio Ghibli but of animation as a whole, this magical adventure turns the wanderings of a lonely ten-year-old girl into an updated â€˜Aliceâ€™s Adventures in Wonderlandâ€™, complete with nods to ancient folklore and modern ecological anxieties. Itâ€™s still the highest-grossing movie in Japanese history.

Magic moment: Parents are transformed into pigs, and our heroine is truly on her own.

Joshua Rothkopf

The greatest ghost story ever told on film, Kenji Mizoguchiâ€™s masterfully macabre fable about two greedy peasants who try to profit from the civil war raging through their country gets more powerful as it slowly bleeds into the supernatural. A sense of the beyond creeps over the movie, as one of the men becomes enchanted with a mysterious noblewoman, taking leave of both his senses and his family in one fell swoop.

Magic Moment: A lakeside picnic with a woman as eerie as the mist that creeps over the water.

David Ehrlich

Advertising

Whatâ€™s left to say about â€˜King Kongâ€™? As Peter Jackson proved a few years back: not very much. Merian C Cooper and Ernest B Schoedsackâ€™s colonialist creature feature is still a stirring and tragic story about why the Empire State Building is such a terrible tourist trap.
